response.answer_text: It's a variation on an old optical illusion known as Pepper's Ghost, which was first demonstrated in 1862 (although is actually quite a bit older): Pepper's ghost  It's basically works like a beam splitter in reverse: instead of taking light from a single source and splitting it into two paths, it takes light from two sources and joins it into a single path, where it can be viewed.   The Haunted Mansion in Disneyland/Disneyworld uses the same sort of illusion to create the ballroom populated by ghosts.  The "smartphone" version basically uses the same idea, with a few wrinkles.  A truncated pyramid of glass is set atop a monitor which draws four versions of the scene which are then reflected by the sloping side.   In essence, each side acts like a partially transparent mirror, and the image that is on the screen is seen as "inside" the pyramid.  Unlike a true hologram, there is no "inter-depth" in the image, it appears as a flat object inside the pyramid, but if you shift sides, you'll view a different version of the object, which can be quite effective.
